{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3298793,"name":"acastagna","username":"acastagna","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a88e4f/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-31T18:16:33.432Z","cooked":"

Is there a trick to getting a calibration with calibdb at a resolution other than 1280x720?
No matter what resoultion I choose the calibration is done at 1280x720. On completing the calibration I get a new 1280x720 json file. How can I calibrate at other resolutions?

I am using an arducam OV9281, but have tried other cameras and other computers as well with no luck.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-01-31T18:16:33.432Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":821,"reads":282,"readers_count":281,"score":4176.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":452798,"topic_slug":"calibrate-with-calibdb","display_username":"acastagna","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17330,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/calibrate-with-calibdb/452798/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3298805,"name":"Owen Busler","username":"Owen_Busler","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/owen_busler/{size}/7684_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-31T18:30:05.290Z","cooked":"

Just noting that we are using photon vision.

What release of photon vision are you using? What board (pi, limelight…)

We do use photonvision with an Orange pi 5, but we are trying to calibrate using calibdb. We have no problem uploading a calibration file into photon vision . The problem is with calibdb not letting us calibrate at different resolutions.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-01-31T20:13:31.782Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":250,"readers_count":249,"score":70.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":452798,"topic_slug":"calibrate-with-calibdb","display_username":"acastagna","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17330,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/calibrate-with-calibdb/452798/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3298954,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-31T21:13:10.148Z","cooked":"

calibdb uses 1280x720 only. There are other resolutions in its database but they are all ratios of that one resolution. PV team asked me to convert essentially that program to Java for integration into PV. I completed my portion and await PV team to complete the integration. In the mean time you could use the standalone phase of the conversion (it isn’t fancy - just a phase being passed through). It does other resolutions but the ChArUcoBoard has small ArUco bits and probably won’t work at very low resolutions. I went with the more modern version of the board so you’ll have to print it again or calibrate with the board on a display. And you can always ratio a calibration to another resolution.

GitHub

GitHub - tom131313/calibrate

Contribute to tom131313/calibrate development by creating an account on GitHub.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-01-31T21:13:10.148Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":231,"readers_count":230,"score":111.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":452798,"topic_slug":"calibrate-with-calibdb","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/tom131313/calibrate/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - tom131313/calibrate","clicks":88}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/calibrate-with-calibdb/452798/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3299107,"name":"acastagna","username":"acastagna","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a88e4f/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-01T00:32:53.222Z","cooked":"

Ahh - I didn’t realize it only does one resolution. Thank you!

We’ll try the code you linked. If we do the scaling I have a few questions:

  • is it as simple as scaling by the ratio of x resolution and y resolution?
  • only works if the aspect ratio is the same?
  • Do all the coefficients get scaled?
","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-02-01T00:32:53.222Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":188,"readers_count":187,"score":57.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":452798,"topic_slug":"calibrate-with-calibdb","display_username":"acastagna","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17330,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/calibrate-with-calibdb/452798/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3299125,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-01T01:09:53.485Z","cooked":"

With all the units being pixels, scale fx and cx by the factor that x changed and similarly scale fy and cy by the factor change for y.

Distortion doesn’t change with resolution.

Thank you - that makes more sense now

I did answer your question and went a little beyond that and there are other possibilities to explore.

PV has a calibration function and recently it was enhanced with a Mr.Cal option. I wasn’t a part of the Mr.Cal work so I must presume it improves calibration but has some sort of downside otherwise it wouldn’t be an option but would have been built into PV calibration.

The PV base calibration statement is exactly the same as the calibdb and my standalone version I suggested. The difference is the calibdb and standalone version provide guidance poses to best calibrate your camera with the minimum number of poses based on the location of the actual distortion it sees and then move automatically to the next pose.

You can simulate those poses in PV if you have a good memory and pose the camera similarly while doing the PV calibration at your desired resolution. Do a few extra poses to cover it and that should be pretty good calibration at your resolution. Compare the calibration at low resolution with the scaled one from high resolution and see if it matters much for your camera.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-02-01T13:23:13.934Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":27,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":167.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":452798,"topic_slug":"calibrate-with-calibdb","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":17330,"username":"acastagna","name":"acastagna","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a88e4f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/calibrate-with-calibdb/452798/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3299440,"name":"Matt","username":"thatmattguy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatmattguy/{size}/222358_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-01T14:16:50.246Z","cooked":"

The mrcal backend is pretty much strictly improved over both our old OpenCV one and calibdb imo. The only value add from calibdb is it tells you where to put the chessboard.

The mrcal website has suggestions on effective calibration dances you can review: How to run a calibration

We are trying to run your GitHub project but there are errors because we need to have several dependencies installed. How were you able to get this running on a Windows laptop? Should we be running this off of a vscode terminal with wpilib installed?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T15:20:01.719Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":86,"readers_count":85,"score":42.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":452798,"topic_slug":"calibrate-with-calibdb","display_username":"L Sao","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54149,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Project Manager"},"post_url":"/t/calibrate-with-calibdb/452798/11","custom_user_title":"Project Manager","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3340691,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T15:40:40.745Z","cooked":"

You didn’t say what part of the project you are trying to run. If you are trying to build the entire program from “scratch” using the source, then I’m not surprised it doesn’t work. That was a “hack” of PhotonVision at the time for the exclusive testing of the calibration program. It is likely very out of date.

I’d expect the released jar to work but I haven’t tried that in months.

To @thatmattguy point the CalibDB and my variation that may or may not someday be put into PV (it’s 99% done waiting for a PV guru to finish it) there isn’t anything special about the calibration itself. What it does is lead you to pick poses that are most effective and efficient at calibrating your camera. Thus the pose coverage can be better and with fewer poses. The Mr.Cal in PV refines the calibration. My version of CalibDB fixes some bugs and in that respect may give better results than the online CalibDB but if you pick wisely yourself the poses then PV is superior. Maybe run CalibDB or my version if it works to get a feel for what poses are useful for your camera then try to duplicate them in PV. That’s probably the best you can do with “simple to use” free software.

Edit P.S. My calibDB was developed on Windows without the PV infrastructure and I’m sure it would be not too hard to put back in what is currently supplied by PV. Not sure why you would want to do that unless you want to own all the code and not rely on PV. I’m not recommending that but it is possible to have only the WPILib and OpenCV dependencies.
